content: Saddened by the passing of Tim Wilson—editor, mentor and friend. https://t.co/SXFuilBmXf
Good discussion with @cigitalgem and Adversa's Eugene Neelou on AI/ML threat risks.  https://t.co/GFUFZnyF8O

Good research and data collection by the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab (@DFRLab ) in creating a massive timeline on the spread of (m/d)isinformation through the 'Stop the Steal' campaign and ending at the Capitol riot. https://t.co/BRzTol6WAf

The statement in the survey: "In fact, one in five has been notified that their personal information has been exposed as the result of a data breach, with a new account opened in 22 percent of these cases." 

So, I would argue 22% of 20% have been "affected," or about 4%. (2/2)

On Veterans Day, I would like to thank all members of the military for their service and dedication to democracy, and remember my late uncle, who served as a radarman in the Pacific in WWII, and then—in only slightly less harrowing work—as a HS teacher and college professor.

Analyzing the National Vulnerability Database along with some expert commentary.
https://t.co/8lfvfKyA5x
Some lessons from looking at jobs data for security, developers, and ops. https://t.co/cKzaAoy54H
Another solid discussion of COVID-19 and strategies to combat its spread, with data and charts, by @tomaspueyo https://t.co/MUVew7E79E
Great epidemic simulator by @gabeeegoooh to show the impact of different countermeasures  and variables https://t.co/sivno3k9ny
Another good article, this time from @washingtonpost that walks through simple simulations showing how social distancing can slow down viral spread. https://t.co/oXAGqSEGcw

The @nytimes does a credible look at the approximate coronavirus risk of different professions based on proximity and interactions. Also note: Many at-risk occupations have the lowest pay and no benefits, incentivizing them to avoid quarantine. https://t.co/xgExOk5IpO
Nice curation of Coronavirus data and some discussion, showing why we are at the beginning of this for most countries. https://t.co/VRAtFUfqDh

Nice investigation into a conservative political op that distributes talking points through sites masquerading as local news. More than 450 sites uncovered, many in early-voting and battleground states. Good visualizations of the connections between sites. https://t.co/B9KrHBQEdW
Nice visualization of the loss in value ($100 billion this year) in certain Silicon Valley ventures. https://t.co/G2MGySpxIK

An important statement from the publisher of the @nytimes: "Care about where your news comes from and how it’s made. … Most of all, carve out a place for journalism in your everyday life and use what you learn to make a difference.” https://t.co/h8Cl0J2tzq

The number of software vulnerabilities more than doubled in 2017, continued to climb in 2018, and looks to be on track to hit a new high this year. Why? I focus on the data, the reasons behind the trend, and why a second surge is likely imminent. https://t.co/AZaasXuvZd

If you know a hacker in middle school or high school, or a student that wants to learn, Phillips Exeter has just started up a capture-the-flag competition. First round ends July 28.  https://t.co/WbhqNTtwoY

An account by a U.S. citizen (and journalist) searched at the border. CBP threatened to bar him from the U.S. (they can't) and went thru his computer, phone, and a journal. https://t.co/YkjmgyHuJP
Info on how to protect yourself vs border searches: https://t.co/kruIoEUpMc

Demonstrating how hard it is to catch supply-chain problems—never mind attacks—NASA discovered an aluminum maker that had been baking test results for 19 years, leading to the failure of two missions. https://t.co/0MA8hMcUjz

"Public relations jobs exceeded those of reporters by more than six-to-one last year, up from less than two-to-one 20 years ago, according to data from the U.S. Census."
https://t.co/UiTCl6haMx

The internet plus click-focused journalism has magnified/distorted our perceptions of crime. (Hint: Data shows it's down; people think it’s up.) Amazon adding an “editor” to create crime stories from doorbell data will only worsen the issue. Good article: https://t.co/0mnv519sB3

Firing of editor-in-chief prompts  five of the site’s seven editorial staff members to resign at The Markup, a yet-to-be-launched  investigative site to focus on the impact of technology. "To fire (EiC) Angwin is to sign The Markup’s death warrant.” https://t.co/O2VFVGilAj

U of Bonn studies the security maturity of developers. Yet, is it surprising that hiring devs for rock-bottom rates from a freelance marketplace results in less than ideal code? Lesson for companies: “You get what you pay for.” https://t.co/edvphxPwAN

First humans—twin girls—altered by genetic editing and CRISPR tech born in China. Scientists “stunned” by breach of ethics. The research team used CRISPR to add HIV immunity to girls, despite non-genetic options existing, arguing father was HIV-positive. https://t.co/XEOHOuINKT

Another reasonable analysis—this time, by @NRO—bolstering the theory that ballot design is to blame. https://t.co/YoyGm9got2 Note, these are non-votes for the Senate race, so a recount is not going to change the outcome. Good to see National Review using a data-based argument.

Good chart from @FiveThirtyEight showing evidence that Broward County’s ballot design may have skewed the senate race toward the Rep. candidate. https://t.co/cFTvvBXiRa Little other data on any other abnormalities. Just a lot of partisan allegations. #MoreElectionDataIsBetter

Kemp will recuse himself from a potential recount after lawsuit filed. A bit late. The only meaningful recount will be on provisional and absentee ballots, since everything else is electronic. Hopefully, this will set future precedent for U.S. elections.
https://t.co/MPC3fKduuE

In a close race for governor, it is surprising that SoS Kemp did not recuse himself. Fmr President Carter, who observes elections worldwide, advised him to resign: https://t.co/U5ppa5lG8L The end result will be less confidence in the result, esp. given his current allegations.

Georgia’s election website has significant vulnerabilities: https://t.co/stgQTrgGqv This should not be a surprise as they were warned in 2016: https://t.co/SW0XM1mr3E And a judge found the same thing in Sept 2018, but allowed elections to continue: https://t.co/cESlC3eGEW

Wired story on why it no longer matters if you have been genetically profiled. “... once a genetic database covers roughly 2% of the adults in a given ethnic population, a match of a third cousin or closer is expected for almost any person of interest.” https://t.co/XYe5fkuKnr

A look into the fake news industry and why one writer writes pay-per-click stories and outright made-up content. Of course, the narrative details could be fake as well, as the writer is using a pen name… https://t.co/MWEzeOjrw9
Good writeup of Knight/Gallup research showing that mainstream media is not biased, it’s the readers who are (simplifying the argument a bit): https://t.co/gNzok7qvcO
Cambridge Analytica operative’s methods are getting a lot more scrutiny, which can only be a good thing. https://t.co/wgdkvFu0Gm
Actual link to “The Race to Build a Cyber Workforce” report: https://t.co/KOGpdIBOVV

Latest tax proposal will levy taxes on struggling grad students by designating stipends as income. https://t.co/AeTKJaAxy2 Along with new limits on charitable contributions, the proposal massively impact higher education and students. https://t.co/tGwCCpdSuz
Wow. GA election server wiped after suit filed. Expert: “People who have nothing to hide don’t behave this way.” https://t.co/p0cCgkub3J
@nselby Boils down to benefit versus risk. Are they there for public service or to satisfy our desire to spectate? It’s arguable is all I’m saying.
@nselby The ransomware thing has been done. https://t.co/ajQIG7oWT3 And note, not everyone who reports on a hurricane is asked to go down into one…
The impact of tech and infoprop on democracy was a major theme in the 2017 threat report by GT (fd: former client). https://t.co/9OLuAghTRI
The best context I’ve seen on the Russian group behind the Facebook ad buys is this 2015 article: https://t.co/tEdBIHxjxX @AdrianChen
@nselby Consider: It’s OK if you replace "outside in the Keys” with “in a warzone” or “among violent protesters.” It’s their job and the story.
NY’s Attorney General has apparently demanded that Equifax remove the language requiring that potential victims agree to arbitration. https://t.co/gD5LD4S7Sb
Equifax: 3 execs who sold stock just days after the firm discovered a security breach weren't aware of the hack. https://t.co/sW3SepaZUZ
… massive targeting of high-value accounts, not to mention other secondary service providers who the last 4 SSN digits are some sort of… 4/n
… was stolen. Now, it’s a certainty. Systems of credit that rely on those 4 identifiers need to be augmented significantly. Expect a … 3/n
Equifax calls it “disappointing,” which is the understatement of the year. Before this, it was likely that every U.S. citizens’ SSN … 2/n
Equifax breach affects 143 mil Americans. Primary consumer identifiers stolen: name, address, SSN, and birthdate https://t.co/G2SQBlqSqk 1/n
When watching the eclipse today, remember safety. Multiple cases of people damaging their eyes in less than 20 secs. https://t.co/Jxf7UlgQS2
Unity patches a remote execution vulnerability in its Windows editor. Millions of developers use it. Patch now. https://t.co/q89jiQnQ2c
Cloudflare CEO has a good post on the difficult nuances of what may seem like an easy decision. https://t.co/GcbmJumXZh
Cool hack of the week, albeit a proof of concept. https://t.co/VdCSUfYhpr
CEO of Swedish security firm had identity stolen; attacker takes out loan and then gets court to declare bankruptcy  https://t.co/3749rH3gy3
“… called our "noble experiment" in self-government.” - Pres. Ronald Reagan, https://t.co/6aN0i1Tb5G -- Happy Independence Day, everyone!
"There is no more essential ingredient than a free, strong, and independent press to our continued success in what the Founding Fathers…” 1/
“… and promptly crash, leaving the worm incomplete--and still hungrily looking for new segments.” Shoch/Hupp 1972, https://t.co/Bg7XLz78Bx

briefly, then be seized by the
worm. The worm would quickly load its program into this new segment; the program would start to run…” 4/n
“…morning, we found dozens of machines dead,  apparently crashed. If one restarted the regular memory diagnostic, it would run very…” 3/n
Fact-based journalism has an uphill battle, as people tend to believe what their candidate says, an MIT study finds. https://t.co/UT8y5wSZDh
A doc that tackles a sig issue for journalists: "'Alternative Facts': how do you cover powerful people who lie?” https://t.co/MyXINUQdBe
Tonight’s must-read: State of Wash. v. President Trump et al. Court orders aren’t usually page-turners, but this is. https://t.co/LrmlstH4S6
Reuters statement on importance of journalism in nations where "media is unwelcome and frequently under attack”  --https://t.co/69TD6RFH83
Two comparisons of EOs: By absolute numbers per year - https://t.co/D9EYy2kW3j and regulations implemented by EO - https://t.co/ONitCszLcp
For those who are counting, Pres. Trump has issued 20 executive orders in the first 10 days. Pres. Obama issued 18. https://t.co/ZR4pSLbm6r
Ironic, but not nefarious. Interesting that it took this level of vetting — journalists looking at voter rolls — to detect, however. https://t.co/Vyegiw1tOI
Crunching numbers shows no link between rubber turf crumb and cancers in Wash. soccer players. https://t.co/hzgjj60xu9 #datasciencefridays
Trusted professions: Top - Nurses/doctors, bottom - congress and car sales. Journalists - 23% of ppl give high marks https://t.co/93bfm6Rdy4
“Journalist” is not the most trusted profession, but charging some for covering protests is not a good precedent. https://t.co/gHke6JRAVw
Nice headline @CBS: "Badlands National Park Twitter account goes rogue, starts tweeting scientific facts” https://t.co/LyI6dnEw7G
Best quote: "If you want someone to love you and you’re in the media, get a dog.” (3/3) @forecasterenten, channelling President Truman.
Upshot: "Press people gossip, yes. But they don’t publish their gossip all the time for good reason.” (2/3)
Clare: "My mother thought journalism frightfully low, like a trade. She didn’t believe anything journalists wrote…” https://t.co/dZpufTybFs
RIP: Clare Hollingworth at 105, a remarkable woman and journalist who broke the news of Germany’s invasion of Poland https://t.co/1XssZRXsxw
And now Russian hackers are apparently focusing on Germany’s political establishment. https://t.co/M5uDGfNzjY
Good narrative article from @nytimes on the evidence for Russia hacking to influence U.S. politics. https://t.co/lNLTIgFn2f
… but, given pre-election hacking and nation-state interest, auditing paper ballots should be SOP, argues @jhalderm: https://t.co/Z2HiqQyymK
Hey Internet. You don’t get to fail until Bruce Schneier (@schneierblog) tells you you can fail. Oh wait… https://t.co/tbyJfEFKAS
My 3-part feature on the use of cyber-insurance by government agencies (mainly local and state) for @govtechnews. https://t.co/nZIO1Hd8eH
An open webcam in Taiwan showing real-time RSA keys for logging in. https://t.co/VUlEqJlycQ
Interesting connection between previous hacks of FinFisher and current HT hack, if claims are reliable. https://t.co/IyFeB1CKIT
Good articles on journalism issues, esp. plagiarism and ethics -- http://t.co/J2AQLcbgPZ @mffisher and http://t.co/Rvbsz8vDA8 @moniguzman
RT @daveaitel: Thinks we are in "Cyber Conflict" not "Cyber War”. < I’ve always used the former term, never the latter.
Two sides of the debate about looking at and reporting on the leaked Sony docs. - Pro: http://t.co/wjfN3dWwMK - Con: http://t.co/7UG61c6NzQ
Heartbleed(TM), Shellshock(R), Sandworm, and … POODLE? Come on, Google, keep up with the pack. Superdeth Poodzilla! #marketinggonecrazy
Congrats to @Stepto on @Amtrak residency. I did a 3-city reporting trip two years ago using Amtrak—lots of fun and very productive.
Cool. My thoughts on digital-physical convergence get extensive treatment by Dan Geer in his #BHUSA keynote: http://t.co/0ErsudHEPQ
RT @sehnaoui: Made me lol. Only hackers will understand :-) http://t.co/a33QoCxVC2 < Or anyone with admin exp and a list of things not to do
RT @TheEconomist @thegrugq: The 60-day state of emergency declared in Bangkok gives the gov't wide-ranging powers http://t.co/HZbjvJe9Ju
Prob not original, but a tweak to the hammer-nail aphorism for security: "When you're a nail, every shadow seems a hammer waiting to pound."
Anyone know what happened to @prvsec and his site? Seems gone from Twitter and site is unresponsive. @upnorthtrip
@nickdepetrillo @quine @collinrm I'll be the first one to criticize the state of journalism, folks. The current model is broken.
@nickdepetrillo Would love to know what technical errors I've made that apparently have you peeved.
@nickdepetrillo No journalist will ever allow you to do that. Of course, I don't laugh at the request, just explain the reasons.
RT @ryanaraine: Legal implications from Marcia Hoffman:  Apple’s Fingerprint ID May Mean You Can’t ‘Take the Fifth’  http://t.co/gkPiX9EiEM
Article from the NYT on NSA's ability to workaround crypto: http://t.co/JPH7qT0c7j Likely  answers some previous q's: http://t.co/1OZqyGZFxM
RT @20committee: A veteran NSA c-int officer looks at the #Snowden case and asks some troubling q's http://t.co/Lv1JM9J6SV < interesting
NZ law enforcement appears to have had access to NSA Prism data in Kim Dotcom case. Anti-terrorism? http://t.co/FRILsMYRn6  ht @daveaitel
Question of the Year: Do data mining and democracy go together? First the NSA revelations, and now this: http://t.co/MER7EG2XIT
RT @SpireSec: @georgevhulme @spacerog here's @roblemos on the topic http://t.co/Y2F2w0KjJ6 < And my latest on eWEEK: http://t.co/vhyhbMa3Q4
Lawyers Granick and Sprigman argue that the NSA's surveillance of Americans is a criminal act: http://t.co/PDg1TpYILK
The NSA only spies on "terrorists," but there is pressure to reclassify activists as terrorists http://t.co/6QQhIUFlnb HT: @stopwatchingus
Pet peeve: Overbroad legal agreements. A summer camp wanted a photo release. It was way over the top, so I cut/pasted my own language.
The success of Google's PageRank was due to mining metadata--links between pages--not content, which its rivals' did. #metadataiscontent
To the people saying, "Of course the NSA is collecting phone records, why r u surprised?" < We're not, but it's important, so talk about it.
If you are a company/group that aided in the Citadel takedown and don't mind talking, feel free to contact me. You know who you are.
Microsoft's largest takedown yet: http://t.co/KYApTCRpHI Reuters got the exclusive: http://t.co/CUL5UjdWnq  Criminals stole $500m, low est.
NY Red Bulls get rivals as @MLS adds 20th team, the NYC Football Club, brought to u by Manchester FC and the Yankees. http://t.co/9euQgLEMA7
RT @thinkhammer:  Why Atlanta should be your next startup HQ. Great read from @roblemos. http://t.co/VuhXaMRh8g < Actually, @lemosrob :)
RT @SarcasticRover: 97% of scientists think that climate change is caused by humans. And 3% think it's caused by Voldemorte.
RT @adschina @markhillary: Did US elec engineer commit suicide, or murdered because he knew too many Chinese secrets? http://t.co/RBnszAvIBF
RT @securityledger: Long Live Endpoint Protection! -says endpoint prot. exec. ;-) http://t.co/vtDpvR1vFp < Reasonable response to my article
RT @dotMudge: Thanks to everyone who proposed to Cyber Fast Track. You contributed to shaking up the government in a very positive way :)
RT @mediagazer: Here lies Web journalism, dead at the hand of the almighty advertiser (@cringely / InfoWorld) http://t.co/Y5F6n5x7Gs < Yep.
@Netseer says, site hacked, not ad service. Browser warnings "completely due to ad serving and corporate website having same domain name."
NetSeer's rep set to "malicious" in whatever engine Google uses. The mal-tag pops up for Netseer results on Google. < @netseer Comment?
RT @securityledger: #Malvertising campaign hits multiple ad networks. < Chrome blocks the page on ZDNet for hosting malicious content. Nice.
RT @lseltzer: RT cool @DarkReading: The Physical Security Factor With Cloud Providershttp://t.co/m7Oahk2R < Thanks, Larry.
After torrential rain thru night and morn, a beautiful spring day in NH today... in January? 55 F. Going back down to 30 F by this evening.
RT @0xcharlie: I think it's disingenuous for #pwn2own to say 'as always' < Doesn't say that now. Was it changed?
So does the pricing on Pwn2Own mean that Mozilla Firefox is the easiest to pwn?
Interesting story on changes in publishing that has allowed at least one author to retain ebook rights. http://t.co/xoMumcDI
Massive Russian cyberespionage network investigated by Kaspersky: http://t.co/cVYFUGSF
In search of data on the bank DDoS attacks: http://t.co/lKmdX2zB

RT @WiredUK: Japanese hacker continues to taunt police with clue strapped to cat: http://t.co/UyODLHDm by @iansteadman
Vulnerability research increasingly goes private, as nation-state attacks show value. Via Info Sec Mag by yours truly: http://t.co/eK09kHTq
It's all feudal. Economist on the feudal battle betwixt Net giants http://t.co/2PjYCUCT,  Schneier on feudal security http://t.co/jfTYsHBu

I would call the Tumblr malware a virus, since it required user interaction, rather than a worm, which does not. Feel free to correct me.
RT @spacerog: Most dramatic before and afters of Sandy I have seen yet, (mouse over) http://t.co/s3mw6eYa < Good use of interactivity.
RT @securityledger: Nice story by @roblemos throwing cold water on Windows 8 bootkit hype: http://t.co/HfSH1M69 < Thanks.
Figuring out how to defend against zombies -- not "zombies" as in bots, but the real thing (sort of) -> http://t.co/LAC53YUr via @teamcymru

Hey Apple, make the iPhone 5 a little longer and you will have the original Newton. Those were the days....
I've seen no outage of GoDaddy or hosted sites. Is it regional?

So, only my IPad is on the UDID list. There was a similar name,  but I got my old iPhone and confirmed it's not on the list. 1 of 5 devices.
For the record, since I'm reporting this story, my iPad2 is definitely on the list and possibly my old iPhone. Otherwise, no comment.

Vat-grown meat http://t.co/Yjl8FYJy Lets hope they don't confuse recipe for meat with their other product: tissue. #SoylentGreenIsPeople

Just blocked Yahoo's app from posting news to my Facebook page. (Yes, I do use it.) Aggregators shouldn't need special apps just to cull PII
Small industry groups, not large government ones, may share information most effectively. http://t.co/dn2ANiNR
What it might actually take to reach the stars... or at least Alpha Centuri. My 2008 Wired article: http://t.co/WduGESyw A bit depressing.
The USS Enterprise project: http://t.co/aytiVnIN < Yes, we're Thermians from the Klaatu Nebula. Large craft? Doable. A Star Trek look? Nah.

U.S. admits to Stuxnet, reports the NYT. Great to know, but leaks of classified info before elections a sad standard. http://t.co/cA5JZQtc
iOS is a house with bars on the windows and a guard at the door: It's hard to figure out if it's a prison or a fortress http://t.co/u4dvyRHS

Interesting that even @mikko is apologizing for the state of AV. Anyone else think tech aimed at mass attacks should also work vs. targeted?
RT @virusbtn: "Most remarkable about Flame is that the Iranian CERT shared samples with Western AV vendors, despite a trade embargo"
